awd_titl_txt: Travel: Student Travel Support for HDF5 User Group (HUG) meeting 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
The HDF5 User group (HUG) meeting 2023, to be held in Columbus, OH from August 16-18th, 2023, will bring together a diverse set of experts to discuss the design, development, and usage of HDF5 libraries and tools that form an ecosystem based on HDF5. The associated presentations and discussions bring a plethora of opportunities for graduate students working in HPC and experimental / observational data management and analysis to get a range of benefits. The HUG meeting is unique in nature. The event will include a set of invited talks from researchers, users, and library developers, who are experts in the field. The event also includes contributed presentations that are submitted through an open call for presentation and selected by the HUG organizing team. The event also contains tutorials and presentations from the HDF5 Group and expert HDF5 developers on tuning and optimization strategies for various HDF5 library components and troubleshooting guidelines. The HUG meeting is organized by a leading group of experts in HDF5 and data management technologies. The project will fund students to participate in the meeting, to engage with the HDF5 research and user community. The funding provided by NSF will have a significant impact on increasing readiness of students for entering the workforce at national laboratories, HPC centers, cloud companies, and academia.

HDF5 (Hierarchical Data Format version 5) provides a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. Due to the versatility of its data model, and its portability, longevity, and efficiency, hundreds of thousands of scientific applications use HDF5 as part of their data management solution. The HUG 2023 meeting organizers are recruiting students wishing to participate in the event from a diverse set of institutions. To increase the participation from the under-represented communities in computer science, the event organizers will engage with communities such as The Ohio LSAMP Alliance. Prospective participants will have to apply, and submissions are evaluated by a committee for scientific merit and for promoting diversity. The students will get several benefits from attending the event, including: (1) exposure to the latest data management, analysis, and I/O technologies (computing platforms, accelerators, and networks), their features, and their impact on designing HPC, cloud, and edge computing software environments; (2) in-depth exposure to the challenges and techniques in designing, developing, and maintaining open-source software environments for HPC systems and cloud environments; (3) exposure to the sustainability aspects of software development; (4) training on systematic tuning and optimization of data management and storage software stacks.; and (5) Interaction with national laboratory and industry professionals related to data management. The project will promote the progress of science as it provides a forum to disseminate research efforts, connect researchers, and train the next generation of diverse workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
High Performance Computing (HPC) systems allow scientists and engineers to tackle grand challenges in their respective domains and make significant contributions to their fields. With the growing volume and heterogeneity of data generated and consumed by HPC applications data management is going through a transformation. In addition, persistent memory and storage hardware and architectures are steadily gaining importance in designing HPC systems in the exascale era. Considering these software and hardware trends, it is increasingly becoming critical to leverage these heterogeneous technologies to design high-performance and scalable software stacks for current and next-generation HPC systems.

It is also becoming critical to train students, researchers, and engineers about these technologies so that the next-generation HPC workforce can fully leverage this technology.

The PI, Co-PI, and their teams have been working in the data management, storage, and I/O R&D areas for nearly 2 decades. The HDF5 library is maintained by The HDF5 Group, a non-profit organization. In specific to the HDF5 technology, the PI’s team has been involved for more than 12 years and collaborates with The HDF Group in bringing the developed technologies developed available to the world. During all these years, the PI’s team contributed to the HDF5 [4] software library (discussed in detail in the following section) and has been able to provide open-source, high-performance, and scalable solutions to the HPC community. HDF5 user community is vibrant, and its users span across the world. HDF5 Forum is an active area for users to exchange ideas and discuss any problems they experience. To bring many of these users into an interaction-intensive sessions, the PI played a critical role in forming the HDF5 User Group (HUG) meetings. A link to the previous HUG meetings is available at hdfgroup.org/hug.

As the HPC field has entered the Exascale era and systems are becoming more complex, it is critical that the next-generation engineers and scientists get exposed to the modern HPC technologies (including persistent memories, fast storage devices such as SSDs, RDMA, etc.), learn how to use the features of these technologies to design HPC software stacks, learn about the process of open-source software developments and its sustainability.

This travel support aimed to achieve the above objectives by encouraging Ph.D. students in the USA working in the HPC area (systems and applications) to participate in the annual HUG ’23 event. A website with call for presentations is now available at The HDF Group website. The HUG event is unique in nature. Topics covered in this event are not covered in other conferences or workshops. The requested student travel fund will help in attracting a set of students (around 10) from a range of US institutions. Their participation will help them to enter the next-generation HPC workforce with increased expertise in software design, reuse, and sustainability.

Major Activities: HUG '23 event was held in a hybrid manner. A total of 97 people attended the conference. Attendees included people from 6 countries (predominantly from USA, 1 to 4 from each of Australia, India, Switzerland, Austria, and Brazil). The top-3 groups of attendees are students (25), industry staff (25), and national lab staff (21).

The student travel funding from NSF allowed achieving increased participation of M.S./Ph.D. students and early-career professionals working in the HPC area (systems and applications) in the HUG ‘23
event. 

The student travel funding from NSF allowed 9 students and early career researchers from different U.S. universities to get be trained in the areas of scientific data management, high performance computing, self-describing data formats, and software development. Out of the 9 students, 6 are female students. The students were also able to interact with leading professionals in the field. They also interacted with students from various other universities (overall student attendance was 25).

The HUG '23 event included a set of tutorials, Keynote Talks, Invited Talks, hands-on sessions and an open mic session.

A special poster session was also organized where the students with travel funding presented their current research results.

The presentations from HUG ‘23 event have been archived under https://www.hdfgroup.org/hug/hug23/hdf5-user-group-hug-meeting-agenda-2023/
